Message.Title: Inside Kindle Fire 2: T3 or S4?
Message.Msg: Packing QC APQ8064 Krait inside Kindle Fire 2 is a real possibility. This SoC is being used in Xiaomi M2 Quad-Core phone, which was announced on Aug 16. See http://www.chinaphonereview.com/xiaomi-m2-quad-core . So from supply side, there is a possibility that Kindle Fire 2 could use QC APQ8064 in quantity (7-12 million units in the first 3 months). Economically, recall that the cost for Nexus 7 is about $152. There is certainly room to pack in a more powerful SoC inside Kindle Fire 2, especially in view of the fact Amazon can sell the device at or below the cost. Historically, we need to review Kindle Fire 1 and Tegra 2 story. Last year, while all signs pointed to the use of Tegra 2, Amazon opted out Tegra 2 and went for TI Omap 4 -- that's an Aamzon stunt. Currently, all analysis and conjecture points to the use of Tegra 3(+) by Kindle fire. Could Amazon pull out a stunt again this time?

Topic.Title: So, the Apple victory is a great start to shutting down Android

Message.Msg: It's actually referred to as "treble damages"...again, just money. The judge doesn't "apply" for anything, wilfullness was already found. The injunction hearing is set for next month, so, no, there is nothing to "re-institute." Moreover, even if an injunction is entered it will be immediately stayed for appeal to the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit...which will take 18-24 months. By then, device shapes will change and infringing interface features will be removed from Samsung devices....and the Android ecosystem will continue to chug right along. Money will be exchanged at some point, but nothing is getting shut down anytime soon, sorry, but you just don't have a clue as to what you are spouting off about. You really shouldn't invite debate on this topic, it is my profession.

Message.Title: NVDA a Winner in Apple dispute
Message.Msg: Shah also sees the latest development in the Apple/Samsung fight as a plus for another chip maker, Nvidia(NVDA_). "We believe Nvidia could benefit from the launch of upcoming HTC One mobile device at T-Mobile," he wrote. "Considering the likely injunction of the Galaxy S 4G and Vibrant, we would expect T-Mobile to promote HTC devices more aggressively." There have recently been rumors that T-Mobile will launch an HTC One X+ smartphone. HTC unveiled its original One X, its first with Nvidia, at the Mobile World Congress event earlier this year. The One X is powered by the chip specialist's Tegra 3 mobile processor. likely injunction....not this year. I think NVDA benefits from being in the HTC, but people need to stop with this silly Apple/Samsung angle.

Message.Title: Lenovo 9" $300
Message.Msg: Lenovo's 9-inch IdeaTab A2109 shows up at Best Buy, flaunts Tegra 3, $300 price tag Lenovo's upcoming IdeaTab A2109 didn't drop in on the FCC with its seven-inch brother, but that hasn't stopped it from reaching stores. The nine-inch device appears to be in stock on Best Buy's online store, offering 16GB of storage, an NVIDA Tegra 3 processor and a standard serving of Ice Cream Sandwich for $299. The slate isn't just available for order, either -- according to Best Buy's stock locator, it can be found in brick and mortar stores too. The A2107, on the other hand, isn't so readily available, but we'll let you know when Lenovo lets it come out to play. article can be found at engadget.com

Topic.Title: Lenovo 9" $300

Message.Msg: Lenovo... will be real curious to see if it sells. I am sure msft is watching very closely at this one. If it does sell... msft will be under so much pressure on winRT. Can't see msft having any choice than to price theirs at $300 or less, i.e. give it away for free to stay in the game, to compete with free or risk getting shut out. Give you a hint boyz, you'd better hope that there will be 1 and only 1 new T3 device coming out in Oct, and not 3. 3 = price is too high it goes no nowhere. Lenova and Asus backing out of winRT is what you'd like to hope for. Unless of course, you are playing for Audis and not Chevys.

Message.Title: Apple Seeks Ban on Eight Samsung Phones in U.S.
Message.Msg: . . What's this from Yahoo? "Sorry. To prevent spam, URLs are not allowed in messages" There goes ibexx's entire career, right boys? Cutting and pasting URL's Anyway, go to bloomberg and type in, "Apple Seeks Ban on Eight Samsung Phones in U.S." And you can read what wahoo's servers think is spam. The Highlights. "Apple Inc. (AAPL), following a trial win against Samsung Electronics Co. (005930), is seeking a U.S. sales ban on eight models of the South Korean company’s smartphones, including several in its Galaxy line, as well as the extension of a preliminary ban on a Samsung tablet computer. Apple, which won more than $1 billion Aug. 24 after a jury found Samsung infringed six of seven patents at stake in the trial, yesterday identified the phones it wants barred in a filing with U.S. District Judge Lucy Koh in San Jose, California. Tab 10.1 Apple, based in Cupertino, California, won a ban on U.S. sales of Samsung’s Galaxy Tab 10.1 tablet in June that the South Korean company said wouldn’t have a significant effect on its business. Apple, which seeks to make that ban permanent, in a court filing yesterday said Koh should also bar U.S. sales of the cellular version of Samsung’s Galaxy Tab 10.1 tablet computer even though the product wasn’t covered by the Aug. 24 verdict. Sales Ban Of the 28 Samsung devices accused by Apple of infringement, the eight targeted for a U.S. sales ban include the Galaxy Prevail, which was the top seller by units in the U.S. from mid-2010 to mid-2012, generating revenue of $378 million, according to data submitted by Samsung in a court filing. Also on Apple’s list are the Galaxy S II Epic 4G, ranked by Samsung as the third-best seller by units in the U.S. among the disputed products; the Galaxy S 4G, the fourth-best; and the Galaxy S II T-Mobile, the eighth-best seller in the U.S. during the past two years. Rounding out Apple’s list of devices targeted for a sales ban are the Galaxy S Showcase, the S II AT&T, the S II Skyrocket and the Droid Charge. With Apple asking for Samsung to pay a $30 licensing fee for each handset the company sells, losing the sales of the handsets Apple is trying to get banned would be less harmful to the company’s financial performance than paying the licensing fee, he said. “If that was applied globally, it would have a Massive Impact on Samsung,” Newman said of the royalty. A royalty of $5 per device would cost Samsung about $1.2 billion a year, Newman said. The injunction will probably be more important than the monetary damages award, Mark Lemley, a Stanford Law School professor, said in an e-mail after the verdict. “The real question is whether this is enough to derail the momentum the Android ecosystem has gained in the marketplace,” Lemley said. The jury also determined that all of Apple’s patents at stake in the trial were valid. Apple also won findings that Samsung devices diluted the value of its so-called trade dress, or how a product looks. The verdict is the fourth-largest jury award in a patent case in U.S. history. Apple rose 2 percent to $675.68 in Nasdaq trading yesterday." .

Topic.Title: Apple Seeks Ban on Eight Samsung Phones in U.S.

Message.Msg: . . "The verdict [against Samsung] is the fourth-largest jury award in a patent case in U.S. history." Jeepers Best, Weren't the paid pumpers boys here tryin' to convince the readers that it was insignificant and didn't matter? They sure were. Wow! "The fourth-largest jury award in a patent case in U.S. history," . .

Topic.Title: Apple Seeks Ban on Eight Samsung Phones in U.S.

Message.Msg: . . So Master? The jury awarded damages of $1,049,343,540.00 to Apple, right? And if the Judge uses her Awesome Powers to triple it, -- it would become $3,148,030,620.00 I wonder if that would be the #1 largest patent infringement award ever? Probably so, right? Apple is always Numero Uno in Everything they do. They're the Best. . .
